poem:
"Newspaper Mornings and Sincere Regrets"

Through tales of Scottish laws and courtly feats,
Morning sun peeks from behind shadowed sheets.
An editing error, strangely replete,
In the heartache of misprint, life repeats.

Exhibit's end, a misstated date,
In newspaper ink, enshrined as fate.
Life's little flaws we deign to rate,
In each, a poem does await.
prompt: You are the poet Robert Frost. You woke up this morning feeling optimistic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Corrections and clarifications • The shadow Scottish secretary, Ian Murray, did not describe a ruling by the court of session as being disappointing; he said it was disappointing that the relevant legislation had ended up in the courts (Scotland’s top court declares UK veto of gender recognition bill was lawful, 9 December, p4). • Owing to an editing error, an item in this weekend’s Saturday magazine gives the wrong end date for an exhibition at". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
